items.title: Google lobs lawsuit at search result scraping firm SerpApi
items.summary: Google says the lawsuit is its last resort.
items.body: Google has filed a lawsuit to protect its search results, targeting a firm called SerpApi that has turned Googleâ€™s 10 blue links into a business. According to Google, SerpApi ignores established law and Googleâ€™s terms to scrape and resell its search engine results pages (SERPs). This is not the first action against SerpApi, but Googleâ€™s decision to go after a scraper could signal a new, more aggressive stance on protecting its search data. SerpApi and similar firms do fulfill a need, but they sit in a legal gray area. Google does not provide an API for its search results, which are based on the worldâ€™s largest and most comprehensive web index. That makes Googleâ€™s SERPs especially valuable in the age of AI. A chatbot canâ€™t summarize web links if it canâ€™t find them, which has led companies like Perplexity to pay for SerpApiâ€™s second-hand Google data. That prompted Reddit to file a lawsuit against SerpApi and Perplexity for grabbing its data from Google results. Google is echoing many of the things Reddit said when it publicized its lawsuit earlier this year. The search giant claims itâ€™s not just doing this to protect itselfâ€”itâ€™s also about protecting the websites it indexes. In Googâ€¦

items.title: The evolution of expendability: Why some ants traded armor for numbers
items.summary: Ants with lots of workers tend to put less energy into making them armored.
items.body: The trade-off between quality and quantity is a fundamental economic dilemma. Now, a team of British, American, and Japanese researchers describes how it applies to biology, as well. They have discovered that this dilemma most likely shaped the evolutionary trajectory of ants, one of Earthâ€™s most successful groups of organisms. Their study reveals that, as ant societies grew in complexity and numbers, they didnâ€™t just make their workers smallerâ€”they also made them cheaper. The cost of armor In the insect world, the exoskeleton known as the cuticle serves as a protective barrier against predators, pathogens, and desiccation, while providing the structural framework for muscle attachment. But this protection comes at a price. Building a robust cuticle requires significant amounts of nitrogen and rare minerals like zinc and manganese. While skimping on armor for an individual insect may be a death sentence, the evolution of ants apparently found a way around it. Read full article Comments

items.title: Switch 2 pub backs off Game Key Cards after leaking lower-cost cartridge options
items.summary: Inin suggests new low-cost options allowed it to "recalculate production" for full cartridge.
items.body: The Switch 2â€™s data-free, download-enabling Game Key Cards have proved controversial with players who worry about long-term ownership and access issues to their purchases. But theyâ€™ve remained popular with publishers that want to save production costs on a boxed Switch 2 game release, since Game Key Cards donâ€™t include any of the expensive flash memory found on a standard Switch 2 cartridge. Now, though, at least one publisher has publicly suggested that Nintendo is offering cheaper Switch 2 cartridge options with smaller storage capacities, lowering production costs in a way that could make full cartridge releases more viable for many games on the console. Earlier this week , R-Type Dimensions III publisher Inin Games explained to customers that it couldnâ€™t switch from Game Key Cards to a â€œfull physical cartridgeâ€ for the retail version of the Switch 2 game without â€œsignificantly rais[ing] manufacturing costs.â€ Those additional costs would â€œforce us to increase the retail price by at least â‚¬15 [about $20],â€ Inin Games wrote at the time. Read full article Comments

items.title: LG TVsâ€™ unremovable Copilot shortcut is the least of smart TVsâ€™ AI problems
items.summary: LG says it'll let people delete the Copilot icon. But TV chatbots aren't going away.
items.body: Online fury erupted this week after an LG TV owner claimed that a firmware update installed unremovable generative AI software on their smart TV. The controversy began on Saturday, when a Reddit user posted about the sudden appearance of a Microsoft Copilot icon on their device (something Windows users are all too familiar with). The Reddit user claimed that a â€œnew software update installed Copilotâ€ onto their LG TV and that it couldnâ€™t be deleted. â€œPre-installed crap is universally dogshit. If I wanted it, Iâ€™d have installed it myself eventually. The whole reason itâ€™s bundled is because no one would choose itâ€¦ Burn your television,â€ another Reddit user responded in the thread, which has 36,000 upvotes as of this writing. Read full article Comments

items.title: Riot Games is making an anti-cheat change that could be rough on older PCs
items.summary: BIOS checks will only affect a limited subset of Valorant players for now.
items.body: At this point, most competitive online multiplayer games on the PC come with some kind of kernel-level anti-cheat software . As weâ€™ve written before , this is software that runs with more elevated privileges than most other apps and games you run on your PC, allowing it to load in earlier and detect advanced methods of cheating. More recently, anti-cheat software has started to require more Windows security features like Secure Boot , a TPM 2.0 module, and virtualization-based memory integrity protection . Riot Games, best known for titles like Valorant and League of Legends and the Vanguard anti-cheat software, has often been one of the earliest to implement new anti-cheat requirements. Thereâ€™s already a long list of checks that systems need to clear before theyâ€™ll be allowed to play Riotâ€™s games online, and now the studio is announcing a new one : a BIOS update requirement that will be imposed on â€œcertain playersâ€ following Riotâ€™s discovery of a UEFI bug that could allow especially dedicated and motivated cheaters to circumvent certain memory protections. In short, the bug affects the input-output memory management unit (IOMMU) â€œon some UEFI-based motherboards from multiple vendâ€¦

items.title: Not too big, not too expensive: The Chevrolet Equinox EV
items.summary: You get quite a lot of EV for the Equinox's sub-$35,000 starting price.
items.body: Thereâ€™s a lot of goodwill out there for the Chevrolet Bolt . As maybe the first properly affordable longer-range electric car on the market, the Bolt wasnâ€™t perfect. It didnâ€™t charge very fast, and people found the seats quite uncomfortable. But it could get more than 230 miles on a single chargeâ€”a lot in 2017â€”and you didnâ€™t have to be flush to afford one. Oh, and it was also pretty good to drive. I know I was a fan from the first time I tried a prototype at CES in 2016. Understandably, Bolt fans were upset when Chevy decided to kill off the car . Yes, it lacked features compared to more modern EVs, but it is also the brandâ€˜s bestselling EV by quite a country mile. â€œNot to worry,â€ said the executives, who told us they had something better coming built on the platform they used to call Ultium but donâ€™t anymore. Starting at around the same $35,000 price tag the Bolt launched with, this would be the new Equinox EV. That $34,995 price tag was perhaps a bit more appealing when the car was eligible for the now-dead $7,500 IRS clean vehicle tax credit. Truth be told, the LT1 spec is a little bare-boned, and youâ€™ll need to step up to the LT2 we testedâ€”which starts at $40,295â€”if you want tâ€¦

items.title: HomeKit Weekly: Aqara Hub M200 brings Matter support and new automation options to HomeKit

Their latest hub, the Aqara Hub M200, replaces their older hubs and features a cleaner design, along with support for Matter.â€¦

items.summary: Crafting a smart home ecosystem can be tricky. There are a lot of product categories, and it can be hard to know which ones to prioritize. Here are some of my go-to smart home recommendations for outfitting a smart home â€” and they all make great gifts this holiday season. moreâ€¦

items.title: Trumpâ€™s energy secretary orders a Washington state coal plant to remain open
items.summary: Chris Wright declared an energy â€œemergencyâ€ in the Pacific Northwest.
items.body: SEATTLEâ€”The last coal-fired power plant in Washington state was set to go cold at the end of the year. It would then switch to natural gas, cutting carbon emissions in half. The shutdown had been in the works for 15 years and was mandated by state law. It required the Canadian energy company that owns the power plant, TransAlta, to retrain workers and ease the local communityâ€™s economic transition. But the farewell to coal was canceled this week by the Trump administration. In furtherance of the presidentâ€™s crusade to keep Americaâ€™s coal plants burning, the Department of Energy announced Tuesday that an â€œemergency existsâ€ in the Pacific Northwest â€œdue to a shortage of electricity.â€ To keep the lights on, Energy Secretary Chris Wright said that the Centralia electric generating facility in southwest Washington must continue to burn coal for at least 90 more days. Read full article Comments

items.title: Instacart agrees to refund subscribers $60 million in FTC settlement
items.summary: The grocery app will also stop hiding refund options and obscuring delivery costs.
items.body: Instacart has agreed to pay out $60 million in subscriber refunds, the Federal Trade Commission announced on Thursday. The refunds will help settle a lawsuit the FTC raised, accusing the grocery delivery app of engaging in â€œnumerous unlawful tactics that harmed shoppers and raised the cost of grocery shopping for Americans.â€ Under the settlementâ€”which expires after 10 yearsâ€”Instacart agreed to stop marketing its app with allegedly deceptive claims. That includes supposedly offering â€œfree delivery,â€ when customers actually paid up to 15 percent in â€œservice feesâ€ not charged for pickup orders. Those service fees, the FTC alleged, were â€œjust delivery fees by another name.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Taylor out of World Championship after 'adverse' drug test
items.summary: Dom Taylor is suspended by the Darts Regulation Authority following an "adverse analytical finding" from a drug test, meaning he is out of the PDC World Championship.

items.title: Apple's USB-C Magic Mouse is back on sale for $68
items.summary: Amazon is selling Apple's USB-C Magic Mouse for $68, which is a discount of 14 percent. This isn't a record-low price, but it's darned close. The mouse typically sells for $79, though today's sale only applies to the white model. It's rare for official Apple accessories to go on sale, and the USB-Câ€¦

items.title: OpenAI adds new teen safety rules to ChatGPT as lawmakers weigh AI standards for minors
items.summary: OpenAI updated its guidelines for how its AI models should behave with users under 18, and published new AI literacy resources for teens and parents. Still, questions remain about how well policies translate into practice.

items.title: Do we have a genuine three-way Scottish title race?
items.summary: Heart of Midlothian continue to lead stumbling Celtic as Rangers continue to improve, so how does that leave the Scottish Premiership title race?

items.title: Smyth signs new three-year deal with Saints
items.summary: Kicker Charlie Smyth signs a new three-year deal and is elevated to the New Orleans Saints' full 53-man roster for the first time.

items.title: Strava puts popular â€œYear in Sportâ€ recap behind an $80 paywall
items.summary: Stravaâ€™s most viral feature is suddenly locked away.
items.body: Earlier this month, Strava, the popular fitness-tracking app, released its annual â€œYear in Sportâ€ wrap-upâ€”a cutesy, animated series of graphics summarizing each userâ€™s athletic achievements. But this year, for the first time, Strava made this feature available only to users with subscriptions ($80 per year), rather than making it free to everyone, as it had been historically since the reviewâ€™s debut in 2016. This decision has roiled numerous Strava users, particularly those who have relished the appâ€™s social encouragement features. One Strava user in India, Shobhit Srivastava, â€œ begged â€ Strava to â€œlet the plebs see their Year in Sport too, please.â€ He later explained to Ars that having this little animated video is more than just a collection of raw numbers. Read full article Comments

items.title: macOS 26.2 adds one of the smartest video calling features Iâ€™ve seen in years

items.title: We asked four AI coding agents to rebuild Minesweeperâ€”the results were explosive
items.summary: How do four modern LLMs do at re-creating a simple Windows gaming classic?
items.body: The idea of using AI to help with computer programming has become a contentious issue. On the one hand, coding agents can make horrific mistakes that require a lot of inefficient human oversight to fix, leading many developers to lose trust in the concept altogether . On the other hand, some coders insist that AI coding agents can be powerful tools and that frontier models are quickly getting better at coding in ways that overcome some of the common problems of the past. To see how effective these modern AI coding tools are becoming, we decided to test four major models with a simple task: re-creating the classic Windows game Minesweeper . Since itâ€™s relatively easy for pattern-matching systems like LLMs to play off of existing code to re-create famous games, we added in one novelty curveball as well. Our straightforward prompt: Read full article Comments

items.title: ByteDance confirms TikTok will be controlled by US owners
items.summary: Closing TikTok deal avoids 2026 ban, but app may be buggy, â€œ100% MAGA.â€
items.body: After a year of stalled negotiations, TikTok owner ByteDance has reportedly agreed to Donald Trumpâ€™s deal giving US owners majority ownership of the app. By signing the agreements, ByteDance has ended a prolonged period of uncertainty for millions of Americans who rely on TikTok for news, entertainment, social connection, and income. Under a law that Trump declined to enforceâ€”which lawmakers convinced the Supreme Court was critical for national securityâ€”TikTok risked a US ban next year if the sale did not go through. According to Reuters , terms of the deal match what was reported in September when Trump controversially confirmed that ByteDance would keep the algorithm . Under the deal, US investors and alliesâ€”including cloud computing firm Oracle, private equity group Silver Lake, and Abu Dhabi-based MGXâ€”will likely license the algorithm. Read full article Comments

items.title: Two space startups prove you donâ€™t need to break the bank to rendezvous in space
items.summary: "We had to push the envelope a little bit here."
items.body: It may be happening quietly, but there is a revolution taking place with in-space transportation, and it opens up a world of possibilities. In January, a small spacecraft built by a California-based company called Impulse Space launched along with a stack of other satellites on a Falcon 9 rocket. Upon reaching orbit, the rocketâ€™s upper stage sent the satellites zipping off on their various missions. And so it went with the Mira spacecraft built by Impulse, which is known as an orbital transfer vehicle. Mira dropped off several small CubeSats and then performed a number of high-thrust maneuvers to demonstrate its capabilities. This was the second flight by a Mira spacecraft, so Impulse Space was eager to continue testing the vehicle in flight. Read full article Comments

items.title: Parasites plagued Roman soldiers at Hadrianâ€™s Wall
items.summary: They were infected by roundworm, whipworm, and microscopic protozoans called Giardia duodenalis.
items.body: It probably sucked to be a Roman soldier guarding Hadrianâ€™s Wall circa the third century CE. W.H. Auden imagined the likely harsh conditions in his poem â€œ Roman Wall Blues ,â€ in which a soldier laments enduring wet wind and rain with â€œlice in my tunic and a cold in my nose.â€ We can now add chronic nausea and bouts of diarrhea to his list of likely woes, thanks to parasitic infections, according to a new paper published in the journal Parasitology. As previously reported , archaeologists can learn a great deal by studying the remains of intestinal parasites in ancient feces. For instance, in 2022, we reported on an analysis of soil samples collected from a stone toilet found within the ruins of a swanky 7th-century BCE villa just outside Jerusalem. That analysis revealed the presence of parasitic eggs from four different species: whipworm, beef/pork tapeworm, roundworm, and pinworm. (Itâ€™s the earliest record of roundworm and pinworm in ancient Israel.) Later that same year, researchers from the University of Cambridge and the University of British Columbia analyzed the residue on an ancient Roman ceramic pot excavated at the site of a 5th-century CE Roman villa at Gerace, a rural dâ€¦

items.body: A couple of hours after a judge formally swore in private astronaut Jared Isaacman as the next administrator of NASA on Thursday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order outlining his space policy objectives for the next three years. The executive order, titled â€œ Ensuring American Space Superiority ,â€ states that the country must â€œpursue a space policy that will extend the reach of human discovery, secure the nationâ€™s vital economic and security interests, unleash commercial development, and lay the foundation for a new space age.â€ White House sets priorities There is nothing Earth-shattering in the new executive order, as much of it builds on previously announced policies that span multiple administrations. There are some notable points in the document that clearly reflect the White Houseâ€™s priorities, though, and Isaacmanâ€™s leadership of NASA. Read full article Comments

items.title: YouTube bans two popular channels that created fake AI movie trailers
items.summary: Google loves AI content, except when it doesn't.
items.body: Google is generally happy to see people using generative AI tools to create content, and itâ€™s doubly happy when they publish it on its platforms. But there are limits to everything. Two YouTube channels that attracted millions of subscribers with AI-generated movie trailers have been shuttered. Screen Culture and KH Studio flooded the site with fake but often believable trailers. The channels, which had a combined audience of more than 2 million subscribers, became a thorn in Googleâ€™s side in early 2025 when other YouTubers began griping about their sudden popularity in the age of AI. The channels produced videos with titles like â€œGTA: San Andreas (2025) Teaser Trailerâ€ and â€œMalcom In The Middle Reboot (2025) First Trailer.â€ Of course, neither of those projects exist, but that didnâ€™t stop them from appearing in user feeds. Google demonetized the channels in early 2025, forcing them to adopt language that made it clear they were not official trailers. The channels were able to monetize again, but the disclaimers were not consistently used. Indeed, many of the most popular videos from those channels in recent months included no â€œparodyâ€ or â€œconcept trailerâ€ disclosures. Now, visitinâ€¦

items.summary: Subscribers will start seeing ads when selecting a user next year.
items.body: Peacock subscribers will see ads immediately upon opening the streaming app or website next year. Itâ€™s a bold new strategy for attracting advertisersâ€”something thatâ€™s been increasingly important to subscription-based streaming servicesâ€”but it also risks alienating viewers As reported by Variety , the new type of ads will display on the profile selection page that shows when a subscriber launches Peacock. Starting next year, instead of the profile page just showing your different Peacock profiles, most of the page will be dominated by an advertorial image. The circles of NBCUniversal-owned characters selected for user profiles will be relegated to a vertical column on the screenâ€™s left side, as you can see here . To avoid seeing what NBCUniversal is calling â€œArrival Adsâ€ every time you open Peacock, you need to subscribe to Peacockâ€™s most expensive plan, which is ad-free and starts at $17 per month (Peacockâ€™s ad-based plans start at $8/month.) items.title: Weâ€™ve finally cracked how to make truly random numbers
items.summary: From machine learning to voting, the workings of the world demand randomisation, but true sources of randomness are surprisingly hard to find. Now quantum mechanics has supplied the answer

items.title: 2025 is the second-hottest year since records began
items.summary: Mean temperatures this year approached 1.5Â°C above the preindustrial average, making it the second hottest year after 2024

items.title: Odd elements in supernova blast might have implications for alien life
items.summary: Some of the elements used by living systems are far more abundant in Cassiopeia A than we thought, hinting that some parts of our galaxy might be more suitable for life than others

items.title: How worried should you be about spending too much time on your phone?
items.summary: Screen time has been linked to all sorts of problems, from depression and obesity to poor sleep. But how worried should you really be? Jacob Aron sifts through the evidence

items.title: What the family drama of interbreeding polar and grizzly bears reveals
items.summary: A hybrid grolar bear saga is unfolding in the Arctic, and the tale of this strange family has much to tell us about nature on our changing planet

items.title: Extreme heat hampers childrenâ€™s early learning
items.summary: Children regularly exposed to temperatures over 30Â°C (86Â°F) have lower scores on literacy and numeracy tests at age 3 to 4, according to UNICEF data from six countries

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.

items.title: Too busy to meditate? Microdosing mindfulness has big health benefits
items.summary: Small bursts of mindfulness practices lasting a minute or less can have unexpected benefits for those with busy lives - hereâ€™s how

items.title: Are we living in a simulation? This experiment could tell us
items.summary: The idea that we might be living in a simulated reality has worried us for centuries. Now physicists have found some tantalising clues â€“ and devised an experiment that might reveal the truth

items.title: Comet 3I/ATLAS from beyond solar system carries key molecule for life
items.summary: Astronomers have discovered that 3I/ATLAS is carrying methanol and other chemicals that were probably important in the origin of life

items.title: Tattooing may trigger localised damage to the immune system
items.summary: There is relatively little information on the long-term health effects of tattooing, but a couple of recent studies suggest the art form might trigger prolonged inflammation

items.title: Hunter-gatherer groups are much less egalitarian than they seem
items.summary: There is a widespread belief that altruism and equality drive social behaviour in traditional hunter-gatherer societies, but the truth is more surprising and complex

items.title: Quantum experiment settles a century-old row between Einstein and Bohr
items.summary: Albert Einstein and Niels Bohr had an ongoing rivalry about the true nature of quantum mechanics, and came up with a thought experiment that could settle the matter. Now, that experiment has finally been performed for real

items.title: How Australian teens are planning to get around their social media ban
items.summary: From legal challenges to lesser-known apps, the teenagers of Australia are already preparing to push back against a law that will see under 16s banned from social media

items.title: England's AI World Cup masterplan - from perfecting penalties to powering players
items.summary: BBC Sport hears from inside the England setup about how artificial intelligence is powering plans for next summer's World Cup.

items.title: AI can influence voters' minds. What does that mean for democracy?
items.summary: Voters change their opinions after interacting with an AI chatbot â€“ but, encouragingly, it seems that AIs rely on facts to influence people

items.title: Why is AI making computers and games consoles more expensive?
items.summary: The AI industry consumes vast amounts of energy, fresh water and investor cash. Now it also needs memory chips - the same ones used in laptops, smartphones and games consoles

items.title: Volcano eruption may have led to the Black Death coming to Europe
items.summary: Climate data and historical accounts suggest that crop failures in the 1340s prompted Italian officials to import grain from eastern Europe, and this may have carried in the plague bacterium

items.title: Images reveal the astonishing complexity of the microscopic world
items.summary: From a dragonfly to marine organisms, photographer Michael Benson zoomed in with powerful scanning electron microscopes to take these extraordinary shots for his book Nanocosmos

items.title: Could the super-rich be cloning themselves? And why would they?
items.summary: Nearly three decades since the remarkable cloning of Dolly the sheep, it has all gone quiet on the human cloning front. Michael Le Page wonders what's happening behind the scenes

items.title: Tigers seem to be bouncing back in remote Sumatran jungle
items.summary: Camera traps in an area of the Leuser rainforest patrolled by NGOs spotted 17 tigers in 2023 and 18 Sumatran tigers in 2024, while surveys elsewhere on the island averaged seven

items.title: Incredible close-up of spider silk wins science photo prize
items.summary: Duelling prairie chickens, a snake-mimicking moth and a once-a-year sunrise at the South Pole feature in the best images from the Royal Society Publishing Photography Competition 2025

items.title: Human challenge trials have never been more popular
items.summary: The ethics of clinical trials that deliberately infect people with a disease aren't clear-cut â€“ but there's a strong case for doing more of them

items.title: Why do I feel lonely even when I'm surrounded by a festive crowd?
items.summary: Feeling alienated in others' company, or "existential isolation", can happen to us all. David Robson digs into the psychological literature for a solution for one reader

items.title: The two standout science-fiction films of 2025
items.summary: From Mickey 17 and M3gan 2.0 to a musical about the end of the world, this was an eclectic year for science-fiction films. Film columnist Simon Ings shares his two breakout hits

items.title: The four best science documentaries of 2025
items.summary: From animal rivals to Jane Goodall's last thoughts, enjoy 2025's best science documentaries, says our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Stop treating your pet like a fur baby â€“ you're damaging its health
items.summary: Pet owners' increasing tendency to see their animals as children rather than dogs or cats can have dire consequences. Owners, and veterinarians, should be wary, warns Eddie Clutton

items.title: The six best science-fiction shows of 2025
items.summary: What were the year's top sci-fi shows? Andor and Severance are still up there, but our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley also has some unexpected tips to share

items.title: Dogs may make us more caring and sociable by changing our microbiome
items.summary: We know that pets influence our microbiome, but scientists have now found that having a dog seems to change this ecosystem in a way that could boost our well-being

items.title: How deliberately giving people illnesses is supercharging medicine
items.summary: The covid-19 pandemic opened the door to once-controversial human challenge trials. Now, volunteers are willingly catching norovirus and influenza to reveal how our immune systems really fight back

items.title: Planned satellite launches could ruin Hubble Space Telescope images
items.summary: More than half a million satellites are planned to launch by the end of the 2030s, and simulations suggest they will have a severe impact on space-based astronomy

items.title: Forming moon may have taken three big impacts early in Earthâ€™s history
items.summary: Conventionally, the moon is thought to have formed during one big impact, but a three-impact model might make more sense

items.title: Ancient human artefacts found near caves in Arabian desert
items.summary: Today, the deserts of the Arabian peninsula are inhospitable â€“ but 100,000 years ago, the area was full of animals and ancient humans

items.title: Why quantum mechanics says the past isnâ€™t real
items.summary: The famous double-slit experiment brings into question the very nature of matter. Its cousin, the quantum eraser experiment, makes us question the very existence of time â€“ and how much we can manipulate it

items.title: Black hole entropy hints at a surprising truth about our universe
items.summary: Two clashing ideas about disorder inside black holes now point to the same strange conclusions, and it could reshape the foundations of how we think about space and time

items.title: Can viral relationship tests really tell you about your relationship?
items.summary: Is there any science to viral relationship tests like the bird test, the orange peel theory and the moon phase test? Emily Impett, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Toronto, has the answers

items.title: Asteroid Bennu carries all the ingredients for life as we know it
items.summary: We knew from prior analyses that a distant asteroid sampled in 2020 carried all but one of the molecules needed to kick-start life, and researchers have just found the missing ingredient: sugar

items.title: Coral reefs have fuelled severe global warming in Earth's past
items.summary: Over the past 250 million years, periods when coral reef growth has peaked have coincided with big rises in sea temperatures

items.title: A sinister, deadly brain protein could reveal the origins of all life
items.summary: We have long struggled to determine how the first living organisms on Earth came together. Now, surprising evidence hints that poorly understood prions may have been the vital missing ingredient

items.title: 'Raise hell' - the fastest bowler you might not have heard of
items.summary: The story of Duncan Spencer, the "frighteningly fast" bowler who could have played for England or Australia.

items.title: Cold-water swimming has benefits for the brain as well as the body
items.summary: There is a growing body of research on the physical benefits of going for a dip in chilly water, but now researchers are starting to find that cold-water swimming may also be reshaping our brains for the better in lasting ways

items.title: What next for friendly foes who see each other 'more than family'?
items.summary: Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz have dominated menâ€™s tennis in 2025. BBC Sport looks at the evolution of their growing rivalry â€“ and where it could go next.

items.title: 'It felt like God's hand on my brain' - the day England were humbled by teenager
items.summary: BBC Sport's From The Ashes series concludes with the inside story of Ashton Agar's record-breaking introduction to Test cricket as a 19-year-old batting at number 11.

items.title: What weâ€™re learning about consciousness from master meditatorsâ€™ brains
